Yes, several minimalist composers eventually gained mainstream success and recognition, especially in the 1980s and 90s. Here are some notable examples:

1. Steve Reich: One of the most influential minimalist composers, Steve Reich gained wider recognition in the 1980s and 90s. In 1998, his album "Music for 18 Musicians" was awarded a Grammy Award for Best Small Ensemble Performance. He has also collaborated with musicians from other genres such as rock, jazz, and classical.

2. Philip Glass: Arguably the most recognized minimalist composer, Philip Glass has achieved unprecedented success in the music industry. He has composed numerous operas, symphonies, and film scores, including the soundtrack for the movie "The Hours," which was nominated for an Academy Award.

3. John Adams: Another important figure in the minimalist movement, John Adams has become one of the most prominent American composers of the twentieth century. His works, which combine elements of minimalism with traditional orchestration, have been performed by some of the world's top orchestras.

4. Michael Nyman: A British composer and pianist, Michael Nyman is known for his work as a film composer, with notable scores including "The Piano" and "Gattaca." His music has been widely recognized and is well-regarded for its incorporation of minimalist techniques.

These composers and others in the minimalist movement have helped to cement minimalism as an important and influential musical movement and have gained recognition and appreciation from a broad spectrum of listeners.
